data.title: Why You Canâ€™t Get a Restaurant Reservation
data.meta_description: Adam Iscoe writes about restaurant-reservation platforms and apps (like Resy, SevenRooms, OpenTable, and Dorsia), bots, and table scalpers.
data.text:
Everyone needs to eat somewhere, and in New York City that place is often a restaurant. New York is a city of long hours, tiny kitchens, cramped apartmentsâ€”and dining out, a lot. There is, improbably, always an occasion: date night, working late, friends in town, New Yearâ€™s Eve, too tired to cook, in-laws, layoff, anniversary, breakup. But getting a decent dinner reservation here is a challenge. Any well-reviewed Italian joint? Youâ€™d better have one. Gourmet burger place? Good luck. The new French-Korean fried-chicken spot? Booked solid for months.

In New York, the neighborhood restaurant doesnâ€™t have much room for neighbors anymore. At Sailor, April Bloomfield and Gabriel Stulmanâ€™s new spot in Fort Greene, reservations are scooped up fourteen days in advance by residents of SoHo, Aspen, and East Hampton, who likely saw the place on some list, or while doomscrolling TikTok or Eater. The majority of diners log on to a restaurantâ€™s Web site at 10:59 A.M., two weeks before they want to eat out, then wait, click, and pray. Pete Wells, who gave Sailor a three-star review in the Times, wrote that although the bar and two booths in front are set aside for walk-ins, reservations â€œdisappear within minutes of being offered.â€ Locals are politely quoted a three-hour wait. Of Roscioli, a downtown outpost of the famous Roman restaurant, the Post wrote, â€œNew Yorkers are risking their lives, begging, bribing and pleading to get a table at the Italian eatery.â€

Since the pandemic, tough reservations have gotten even tougher. (One poll indicated that, during lockdown, people missed restaurants more than they missed their friends and family.) To sidestep the reservation scrum, particularly at a hundred and fifty of the cityâ€™s buzziest restaurants, a new squad of businesses, tech impresarios, and digital legmen has sprung up, offering to help diners cut through the reservation red tape, for a price. In the new world order, desirable reservations are like currency; booking confirmations for 4 Charles Prime Rib, a clubby West Village steakhouse, have recently been spotted on Hinge and Tinder profiles.

A certain kind of fat cat has always had someone elseâ€”a secretary, a concierge, the butlerâ€”make reservations. For regular people, though, booking a table at all but the most exclusive restaurantsâ€”Le Pavillon in the fifties, the Four Seasons in the sixties, Sign of the Dove in the seventies, Le Cirque in the eighties, Per Se in the two-thousandsâ€”required only a telephone.

â€œMy whole career, thatâ€™s what you did,â€ Michael Cecchi-Azzolina, who worked as a maÃ®tre dâ€™ in the eighties and nineties, told me. Reservationists were trained to pick up the phone within three rings; theyâ€™d write the name in a log, underlining V.I.P.s twice. â€œAnd you damn well knew every customer,â€ he said. If a regular or a celebrity showed up without a reservation, Cecchi-Azzolina usually squeezed them in. â€œThereâ€™s some kind of alchemy in the restaurant world,â€ he said. â€œSomebody cancels, somebodyâ€™s late, and youâ€™re out of the weeds.â€ One night, when he worked at the River CafÃ©, in Brooklyn, a man palmed him six hundred dollars for a table. He said he could tell the denomination of the bills by the feel of the paper in his hand: tens and twenties were worn, hundreds were crisp.

In 2024, plenty of diners are willing to part with six hundred bucks for a table, too, but they are likely paying it to a stranger, via an app.

Ben Leventhal, who co-founded the reservation site Resy, in 2014, agreed to meet me for dinner to fill me in on the new restaurant-booking landscape. He left Resy four years ago, after American Express bought the company, and he has since created a customer-loyalty app called Blackbird, which doesnâ€™t make bookings but rewards customers with the restaurant equivalent of frequent-flyer points. Earlier, heâ€™d told me, â€œThe average diner in New York City is massively disadvantaged, and they donâ€™t even know it. Itâ€™s as if theyâ€™re bringing a knife to a gunfight.â€ Heâ€™d suggested we meet at Ralph Laurenâ€™s Polo Bar, on East Fifty-fifth Streetâ€”one of the most sought-after tables in town. (He booked it.) I found him, wearing a trim blue suit and sitting at a table by a fireplace in the equestrian-themed bar. (You also need a reservation to get a drink; I watched as a hostess in a camel-hair coat gently turned away a well-dressed couple who looked unaccustomed to being disappointed.) Leventhal ordered a tequila and jumped right in, â€œmapping the reservations ecosystem,â€ as he called it, on a cocktail napkin.

His list of possible approaches went like this: phone call, e-mail, Instagram D.M., in-person (â€œBefore you leave a place, you could make another reservation. Itâ€™s a great way to get oneâ€), texting someone you know (the maÃ®tre dâ€™, a chef, even servers and line cooks), hotel concierges (some residential buildingsâ€”432 Park Avenue, 15 Hudson Yardsâ€”have their own), Ã©lite credit-card partners (â€œChase has tables, Amex has tablesâ€), membership reservation clubs like Dorsia, new apps (TableOne claims to show every available publicly listed reservation at the most in-demand restaurants, in real time), secondary marketplaces (in the manner of ticket scalpers, Web sites like Cita Marketplace and Appointment Trader will sell you a reservation, often procured by a bot, usually made in someone elseâ€™s name), the restaurantâ€™s Web site, and online-reservation systems (OpenTable, Resy, Tock, Yelp). Leventhal described this last category, by far the most common way to book a table, as â€œthe land of democracy, the land of first come, first served.â€ Then he smirked and said, â€œIn theory.â€

Nearby, a woman in red sipped champagne; across the room, a young woman wept. A manager strolling by recognized Leventhal and asked about the inked-up cocktail napkin. â€œAre you doing math?â€ she asked.

â€œWeâ€™re trying to figure out how reservations work,â€ he said.

â€œItâ€™s an art, and a game of Tetris,â€ the manager, a blond woman in her thirties, said. â€œSome people really get off on saying no. When we have to say no, it feels terrible. People say, â€˜What if I was with Leonardo DiCaprio?â€™ And Iâ€™m, like, â€˜Are you?â€™ â€

Downstairs in the dining room, the maÃ®tre dâ€™, Nelly Moudime, greeted Leventhal warmly and asked him where he wanted to sit. When Resy started, the app sold reservations for about ten per cent of a dinerâ€™s average check. (The Times called it â€œthe next step in the devolution of New York hospitality.â€) After public outcry, Resy changed its model: restaurants pay a small monthly fee; diners donâ€™t pay for reservations. â€œBut we now have a customer who fundamentally believes thereâ€™s a price for everything,â€ Leventhal said, frowning. â€œNot everything should be purchasableâ€”which makes peopleâ€™s heads explode. You canâ€™t call up Polo Bar and say, â€˜How much will it cost to get in?â€™ â€

You can, however, call up Polo Bar, wait fifty minutes on hold, make a reservation, and then resell it online. (Before meeting me for dinner, Leventhal texted me a screenshot of a Cita page, where a five-oâ€™clock table at Polo Bar was listed for four hundred dollars.)

Moudime, who wore shimmering silver-sequin pants, dropped by our table to chat. She said that a woman had recently called for a last-minute reservation, saying that her mother had just recovered from cancer and wanted to celebrate at Polo Bar. At 5:30 P.M., three young people showed up for the table: no mom, no cancer. â€œWe still took care of them,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s the new world we live in. And, I think, maybe, we created that monster.â€

On a recent Thursday morning, I stopped by Roscioli. Like many hot restaurants, Roscioli usually has tables for famous people, investors, other chefs, and regulars. But most are snapped up on Resy as soon as they become available. Amelia Giordano, Roscioliâ€™s reservationist, invited me to sit with her in the empty restaurant, the walls lined with bottles of wine, and watch her iPadâ€™s screen as the tables filled up for fourteen days hence.

At 10 A.M. sharp, someone booked a four-top, for 5:45 P.M. By 10:01, there were seven reservations, including two for birthdays. Names started madly flashing on the screen. 10:03: â€œEverything but the later tables have booked,â€ Giordano said. 10:06: fully committed.

At least a handful of those reservations were made by people who would never cross Roscioliâ€™s threshold.

In May, 2021, a thirty-three-year-old software engineer named Jonas Frey couldnâ€™t get a reservation to renew his driverâ€™s license at the Nevada D.M.V., so he built a Web site to solve the problem. â€œI thought, â€˜How is it possible that I canâ€™t pay for a spot in line?â€™ â€ he told me. That July, after scoring a twenty-two-thousand-dollar break on rent from his landlord, maxing out his credit cards, and staying up all night coding in his underwear for two months (â€œMy wife was just bringing me Red Bull and pizza,â€ he said), Frey launched Appointment Trader, an online marketplace for people to buy and sell reservationsâ€”everything from private shopping experiences (the HermÃ¨s store in Paris), doctorsâ€™ appointments (a hot commodity in Miami and Beverly Hills), and tables at restaurants all over the world.

The Web site resembles an artifact from the early days of the Internet: with its flashy banners and simple menus, it almost looks like eBay circa 1995. â€œWe get a lot of smack for it being ugly,â€ Frey said, adding that it hasnâ€™t hurt business. Appointment Trader cleared almost six million dollars in reservation sales during the past twelve months, a more than twofold increase from last year. New users create an account with their e-mail address to buy or sell reservations; sellers compete to earn â€œTraderpointsâ€ and â€œmedals,â€ which allow them to upload more reservations and thereby make more money. Frey takes a twenty- to thirty-per-cent commission.

Prospective buyers browse a list of restaurants organized by locale. Frey designed an algorithm that determines the most popular places based on reservation requests; in New York, 4 Charles, Tatiana (an Afro-Caribbean place at Lincoln Center), and COQODAQ (Flatiron Korean fried chicken) currently top the list. Users can click around a glitchy Google Maps plug-in, or type a restaurantâ€™s name in the search bar. You can buy a limited selection of â€œinstantly available reservationsâ€â€”an indoor Friday-night four-top at Don Angie, a modern Village trattoria, for two hundred and twenty-five dollarsâ€”or place a bid, for a restaurant and a time of your choosing. Then individual resellers (for instance, FlirtatiousCanvas69, ExpeditiousFork45) can accept the bid and fulfill it by any means necessary. The buyer is informed of what name to give when he or she shows up to claim the table. (This can lead to awkward moments at the host stand, particularly for couples on dates: men sometimes are obliged to give other womenâ€™s names and fumble for phone numbersâ€”the name and number on the purchased reservation.)

The afternoon before I met Leventhal at Polo Bar, I logged in to Appointment Trader, which recommended that I place a â€œbidâ€ of at least three hundred and fifty-five dollars for a two-top there. I started by offering a couple hundred: â€œğŸ¥± Your bid price is below average,â€ the site shot back. Then I upped the bid to the recommended amount: â€œğŸ¤– Did we say warmed up? Now you got those mercenaries, bots and hustlers on ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥.â€

So who are the resellers, mercenaries, and hustlers who provide Appointment Trader with prime tables? Some are people who sit with OpenTable or Resy pulled up on their laptops every morning, amassing reservations in various names. Some are kids who borrow their parentsâ€™ Amex black cards, telephone Amexâ€™s Centurion concierge, and book hard-to-get tables that are set aside for card users. Others call in favors with friends in the industry, bribe maÃ®tre dâ€™s, or e-mail reservationists with made-up storiesâ€”a diehard foodie visiting town (â€œwe have always been desperate to come and try your delicious looking Lasagna!â€), or pretending to be the Queen of Morocco or the sister of the King of Saudi Arabia. The chef Eric Ripert, of Le Bernardin, widely considered one of the best restaurants in the world, told me that itâ€™s not uncommon for callers to scream at and even threaten his reservationists.

Alex Eisler, a sophomore at Brown University who studies applied math and computer science, regularly uses fake phone numbers and e-mail addresses to make reservations. When he calls Polo Bar, he told me, â€œSometimes they recognize my voice, so I have to do different accents. I have to act like a girl sometimes.â€ He switched into a bad falsetto: â€œIâ€™m, like, â€˜Hiiii, is it possible to book a reservation?â€™ I have a few Resy accounts that have female names.â€ His recent sales on Appointment Trader, where his screen name is GloriousSeed75, include a lunch table at Maison Close, which he sold for eight hundred and fifty-five dollars, and a reservation at Carbone, the Village red-sauce place frequented by the Rolex-and-HermÃ¨s crowd, which fetched a thousand and fifty dollars. Last year, he made seventy thousand dollars reselling reservations.

Another reseller, PerceptiveWash44, told me that he makes reservations while watching TV. He was standing outside the break room at the West Coast hotel where he works as a concierge. â€œItâ€™s, like, some people play Candy Crush on their phone. I play â€˜Dinner Reservations,â€™ â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s just a way to pass the time.â€ Last year, he made eighty thousand dollars reselling reservations. Heâ€™s good at anticipating what spots will be most in demand, and his profile on the site ranks him as having a â€œ99% Positive Sales Historyâ€ over his last two hundred transactions. It also notes that he made almost two thousand reservations that never soldâ€”a restaurateurâ€™s nightmare.

Some resellers use botsâ€”basically, computers that are faster at hitting the refresh button than you are. Several bots might be simultaneously checking the app, ten or even a hundred times per second, twenty-four hours a day, until one finds the eight-oâ€™clock table at Bangkok Supper Club that itâ€™s been programmed to grab. Instead of using a keyboard or mouse, the bot programmatically executes the reservation appâ€™s underlying code. Some resellers subscribe to such sites as Resy Sniper (fifty bucks a month), which uses custom-built bots to snag tough reservations; some use open-source code posted on GitHub or write their own.

In addition to hotel concierges, restaurant employees (maÃ®tre dâ€™s, hosts, line cooks) also sell tables on Appointment Trader, risking their jobs for quick cash. Frey explained, â€œYouâ€™re essentially, virtually, greasing the palmâ€”without ever meeting the guy.â€

The origin of the restaurant reservation is murkier than the origin of the restaurant. As Rebecca L. Spang writes in â€œThe Invention of the Restaurant: Paris and Modern Gastronomic Culture,â€ in the eighteenth century, dining out in Paris or London meant going to a tavern where dinner was served at a common table, until the food ran outâ€”first come, first served. In the U.S., reservations began to be more common sometime after the turn of the century, when it became popular to dine out for special occasions: Christmas, New Yearâ€™s Eve, Election Night. More commonly, wealthy men â€œreservedâ€ private rooms at restaurants to entertain guests. (In New York, people vied to host the most elaborate private dinners: at one, the center of a huge table at Delmonicoâ€™s was removed and replaced with a water tank, for a centerpiece of four swans on loan from Prospect Park.)

In the twentieth century, the growth of the middle class, suburbanization, and the advent of the newspaper restaurant review made telephone reservations the normâ€”until the Internet changed everything. In the late nineties, after movies, rental cars, hotels, and airlines had moved advance booking online, Web sites like Savvydiner.com started brokering restaurant reservations. Diners would click a button, prompting a Savvydiner employee to telephone a restaurantâ€™s maÃ®tre dâ€™, who scrawled the name in his book, next to all the other people who werenâ€™t yet precipitating the end of an era.

By 1999, a crop of new Web sitesâ€”RSVIP.com, Reservemytable.com, Foodline.com, OpenTable.comâ€”were competing to automate the process. Tavern on the Greenâ€™s owner, Warner LeRoy, started taking reservations on the restaurantâ€™s Web site. Other restaurateurs were skeptical. OpenTable charged restaurants a monthly fee, plus a dollar for every guest seated. Asked by a reporter what he thought about online reservations, the director of operations at Danny Meyerâ€™s Union Square Cafe scoffed, â€œThere is no substitute for a kind, human voice on the phone.â€™â€™ But Meyer became an early investor in OpenTable, and, later, in Resy. Last year, he invested in an A.I.-powered reservation platform called SevenRooms, which most people havenâ€™t heard about because itâ€™s been designed for diners not to know it exists.

To be clear: every night in New York, there are hundreds of perfectly good seven-thirty tables available at perfectly good restaurants. For a lot of diners, though, the pleasure is in the scarcity; and the smaller, noisier, and more crowded a restaurant is, the better. Some restaurateurs claim to hate the buzz that comes with being popular. Ariel Arce, who operates Roscioli, told me, â€œIf itâ€™s a room full of people who just flock there for a reservation, the vibe ainâ€™t gonna be very fun.â€ Roni Mazumdar, who owns the Unapologetic Foods group (Semma, Dhamaka, Adda Indian Canteen), told me, â€œWe only value one thing: those who care about us. How do we know you care about us? When you show up and you are cordial to the staff.â€ He showed me an e-mail with the subject line â€œUrgent VVIP Request,â€ from a high-end concierge service that also brokers yacht sales (mission statement: â€œDedicated to understanding everything you want and giving you more than you imaginedâ€), demanding a five-top for an extremely powerful person, who â€œrepresents Matthew McConaughey, Scarlett Johansson, Chris Rock, Katherine Heigl and Tony Hawk.â€ Mazumdarâ€™s team sent a reply saying that the client could try to reserve through Resy.

In 2022, Justin and Hailey Bieber were politely turned away by Carbone when they showed up without a reservation. In February, Hailey and her entourage had dinner at 4 Charles, after a private reservationist named Nicky DiMaggio secured them a table. DiMaggio, who charges between five hundred and a thousand dollars per reservation, owns a sanitation business with more than forty garbage trucks. He got into the reservation game when he was a teen-ager, after his cousin got him a reservation at Raoâ€™s, the impregnable mob-flavored restaurant in East Harlem. He usually works with referrals. â€œMy client list is, like, the N.B.A., Megan Fox,â€ he told me. (DiMaggio also claims that he has worked with reps for Serena Williams, a son of Italyâ€™s Vice-President, a manager at a Rolex store, and a lot of Goldman Sachs guys.) DiMaggio, who is thirty-three, books the tables in his own name (to protect his clientsâ€™ privacy, he says). Last year, he made more than a thousand reservations at the cityâ€™s trendiest restaurants; he claims to have cozied up to the owners and managers, who set aside tables for him. In reality, he has used Appointment Trader, just like everyone else.

In Bret Easton Ellisâ€™s novel â€œAmerican Psycho,â€ the sociopathic Wall Street protagonist is obsessed with a fictional restaurant called Dorsiaâ€”a place so exclusive as to be almost mythical. A new, members-only app by the same name promises to deliver what the status-mad bros in the novel cannot secure for themselves: a tough table. Aspiring users download the app and allow it to scan their contacts (â€œThe fastest way to get in is with your network,â€ the site declares), and then answer a few questions: employer, job title, Instagram handle, LinkedIn URL. Dorsia is trying to figure out if you are the kind of person who will shell out.

If you pass muster (I only did, I think, because I had saved the numbers of a lot of chefs in my contacts while reporting this piece), you can log on to Dorsia and search for the solidly booked restaurant of your choice. (You enter your credit-card information immediately, of course.) The first reservation I spotted was an eight-oâ€™clock Saturday two-top at Carbone; there was also a slew of prime-time tables at Le Gratin, one of Daniel Bouludâ€™s offshoots. Then I read the fine print: the table at Carbone would cost me a thousand dollarsâ€”not as a booking fee but as a prepayment for the meal. For two of us to get our moneyâ€™s worth, weâ€™d have to down three plates of Calamari Marco, three orders of lobster ravioli, two veal Marsalas, a funghi trifolati, and two bottles of Barolo Gramolere.

Restaurants that utilize Dorsia see it as a way to collect data about their customers, and also to increase revenue by guaranteeing that those customers are big spenders. Other minimum prepayments listed on the app: two hundred and eighty-five dollars per person at Le Pavillon, Bouludâ€™s midtown seafood palace; two hundred and thirty-five at Marea, on Central Park South; and three hundred at Torrisi (on a Monday), a sister restaurant to Carbone. This summer, as Dorsiaâ€™s members go on vacation, the app promises to be ready with tables at the chicest restaurants in Ibiza, in Mykonos, and along the French Riviera and the Amalfi Coast.

In promotional materials for restaurateurs considering listing their tables on the app, Dorsia claims that it saves twenty minutes per party (no waiting for the check) and so helps turn tables fasterâ€”a key to restaurant solvency. (Gabriel Stulman, of Sailor, which is not on Dorsia, told me that he needs to turn his tables three times a night to make money.) Still, several restaurateurs who have opted out told me that they find the colossal-prepay concept unseemly, in part because it encourages binge eating. â€œItâ€™s psychotic,â€ one owner said. â€œWe donâ€™t want to put people in that situation.â€

Dorsia understands that, like the N.S.A. and TikTok, successful restaurants know more about us than we want to imagine. How many times have you eaten there? Are you a friendly regular, an asshole neighbor, an expense-account out-of-towner? Do you prefer a cocktail or the house white? Do you linger after coffee? In the old days, much of that informationâ€”and your wifeâ€™s birthday, your secretaryâ€™s nameâ€”lived inside a maÃ®tre dâ€™s head. Many restaurants have always kept handwritten notes on their guests, relying on abbreviations: â€œH.S.M.â€ (heavyset man), â€œeagleâ€ (bald guest), â€œo-oâ€ (wears glasses), â€œl.o.l.â€ (little old lady). These days, guest notes are â€œdata,â€ which tech platforms help restaurants keep track of. Oenophiles might be labelled â€œW.W.â€ (wine whale), or, simply, â€œdrops coin.â€ If you got a surprise appetizer on the house, you might have been marked down with â€œS.F.N.â€ (something for nothing), or â€œN.P.R.â€ (nice people get rewards). Did you sit for hours over a bowl of soup, tip poorly, get wasted, or shush the young family sitting at the next table? You might be demoted to â€œP.N.G.â€ (persona non grata) or â€œD.N.S.â€ (do not serve) status.

Resy has a data-driven feature called Notify, which puts diners on a waiting list for a restaurant. (OpenTable and SevenRooms added similar features to compete.) Using it is a little like buying a fistful of lottery tickets. Diners add themselves to lots of restaurantsâ€™ Notify lists for a certain night with the hope of scoring just one. The moment a host decides that a table is a no-show, or if thereâ€™s a cancellation, a push notificationâ€”â€œNew Table Alertâ€â€”is sent to everyone on the Notify list for that night. The table goes to whoever claims it first on the app. Curious, I added my name to the Notify list at every fully booked restaurant in my neighborhood, over a six-week period. I didnâ€™t get a single e-mail or notification.

I thought I just had bad luck, until a conversation with Resyâ€™s C.E.O., Pablo Rivero, clarified things. Over dinner at Txikito, a buzzy Basque restaurant in Chelsea, he explained that I would likely always be near the bottom of the Notify queue. After American Express acquired Resy, in 2019, anyone with a fancy Amex cardâ€”Centurion, Platinum, Reserve, or Aspireâ€”has an advantage. If you have one of these cards (Centurion: ten-thousand-dollar initiation fee, five thousand dollars per year), Rivero said, â€œYou will get a Resy notification before other people do.â€ (He also said, somewhat puzzlingly, â€œWhat we are trying to do is, honestly, democratize dining a bit more.â€)

Some restaurants sort their virtual waiting lists themselves, without help from Amex. These managers cherry-pick V.I.P.s and regulars from their Notify queues. SevenRooms, Resyâ€™s newest competitor, has a tool that has largely automated that process: an algorithm picks which diners get priority push notifications about late openings. The criteria include how often a diner visits, how big his or her tabs are, how much wine and dessert are ordered, and tip size.

Joel Montaniel, SevenRoomsâ€™ C.E.O., told me, â€œItâ€™s the system thatâ€™s automatically tagging and segmenting people, because we know the human mind is generally limited, and not every customer is going to get caught and tagged appropriately.â€ (Restaurateurs can also input guest notes manually.) SevenRooms scans customersâ€™ bills, tracks referrals, and monitors guestsâ€™ online reviews; people who frequently cancel or no-show can be required to provide a credit-card deposit. In January, the percentage of restaurants on Resy that charged cancellation fees had grown more than fourfold from pre-pandemic levels.

Restaurants also want to know about your guests. Debby Soo, the C.E.O. of OpenTable, told me, â€œItâ€™s not just the person who booked. If there are four people, they want to know all four of those people.â€ Diner profiles and guest notes are useful for deciding who lands a table and also where to seat peopleâ€”Siberia or a cozy booth? (A new startup, Tablz, offers diners the opportunity to pay between five and a hundred dollars to reserve their favorite tables at select New York restaurants.)

At Polo Bar, Leventhal had talked a lot about the challenge that restaurants face in deciding who to let in the door: â€œWe need restaurants to be democratic,â€ he said (a sentiment I heard over and over). â€œBut they canâ€™t beâ€”in order for them to be sustainable. The margins are so thin, and thereâ€™s not enough room for everyone.â€ Thatâ€™s why restaurants like to identify and reward V.I.P. and regular customers. If a restaurant deems you important enoughâ€”and decides to label you as a â€œV.I.P.,â€ â€œP.P.X.,â€ (personne particuliÃ¨rement extraordinaire), â€œreg,â€ â€œ$$$$â€ or â€œsoiâ€ (short for soignÃ©) on its in-house systemâ€”you might notice a little gold-and-black crown emoji and more available tables next time you sign in to Resy.

â€œGood operators know the best practice is saying yes, but how do you say yes while maximizing revenue?â€ Leventhal said. â€œItâ€™s about saying yes to the person whoâ€™s going to spend the most money over the long haul.â€

Moudime, the Polo Bar maÃ®tre dâ€™, agreedâ€”to a point. â€œCheck average is good. But itâ€™s not everything,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™ve got your big wine spenders, but do they come every night? No. Does a celebrity come every night? No! A restaurant works by an everyday person coming regularly.â€

Your Resy, OpenTable, and SevenRooms profiles follow you around town, like Uber reviews, or chlamydia. If you ordered a bottle of 1968 Mastroberardino Taurasi at Carbone, the staff at Major Food Groupâ€™s dozens of affiliated restaurantsâ€”Dirty French, ZZâ€™s Clubâ€”can find out and fuss over you accordingly.

Guest data is not shared between restaurants with different owners, but platforms like SevenRooms and Blackbird want to change that. SevenRoomsâ€™ Montaniel envisions partnerships between restaurant groups to â€œmake the world a private member club for everyone.â€ Leventhalâ€™s solution, at Blackbird, is to reward diners with something like frequent-flier points, which can be redeemed for cocktails and appetizers at any participating restaurant. (Blackbirdâ€™s slogan: â€œBe a regular, everywhere.â€) The company, which uses blockchain technology, charges a fee to participating restaurants and some member diners, and publishes an insiderish newsletter called â€œThe Supersonic.â€

The desire to amass data on diners is one reason that restaurateurs hate the resale sites. When you buy a reservation from Cita or Appointment Trader, you have to give the maÃ®tre dâ€™ a fake name to claim your table. How does Polo Bar know to give you a complimentary Martini, or what your water preference or food allergies might be, when they donâ€™t even know your real name? (In January, 4 Charles e-mailed one diner whom it suspected of dealing in bot-acquired reservations, â€œWe will require photo I.D.â€)

This kind of protocol risks making diners feel like theyâ€™re in a T.S.A.-screening line. Restaurants donâ€™t like it either. â€œItâ€™s bad for business,â€ Eric Ripert, at Le Bernardin, told me. â€œEvery day, we spend hours trying to track down the bots and the fake reservations. Last week, we caught eight fake reservations.â€ Unusual e-mail addresses and disconnected phone lines are a dead giveaway; reservationists always call or text to confirm. He went on, â€œIf you have tables that are no-shows, the profit of the night is done. So, we cannot lose reservations!â€
